newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine '97 budget may be passed in April - speaker.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine '97 budget may be passed in April - speaker.

text.p: Ukraine's long overdue budget, which will pave the way for a sizeable long-term credit from the International Monetary Fund (IMF), will be further delayed into April, the speaker of parliament said on Tuesday.
Olexander Moroz blamed the government for not submitting for debate a final budget document incorporating changes suggested by parliament last December.
"The budget will be passed two weeks after the government releases it to us, but until now we have received nothing from them," Moroz said at a news conference.
The government has urged parliamentary deputies to approve the budget, together with a tax reform package to underpin it, by the end of the first quarter.

The draft budget foresees Ukraine's first growth since independence in 1991, and initial versions called for a deficit of 5.5 percent of gross domestic product -- or four percent by Western calculations -- and annual inflation of 25 percent.
In the absence of a 1997 budget, parliament has extended the 1996 budget into this year to cover spending.

President Leonid Kuchma said this week he would not sign an "unrealistic" budget which does not include changes to the tax system, but added that he would not pass a budget by decree because it would violate the Ukrainian Constitution.
